title:
Global well-posedness and relaxation for solutions of the
  Fokker-Planck-Alignment equations

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper we prove global existence of weak solutions, their regularization, and global relaxation to Maxwellian for a broad class of Fokker-Planck-Alignment models which appear in collective dynamics. The main feature of these results, as opposed to previously known ones, is the lack of regularity or no-vacuum requirements on the initial data. With a particular application to the classical kinetic CuckerSmale model, we demonstrate that any bounded data with finite energy, $\left(1+|v|^{2}\right) f_{0} \in L^{1}, f_{0} \in L^{\infty}$, and finite higher moment $|v|^{q} f \in L^{2}, q \gg 2$, gives rise to a global instantly smooth solution, satisfying entropy equality and relaxing exponentially fast.

The results are achieved through the use of a new thickness-based renormalization procedure, which circumvents the problem of degenerate diffusion in non-perturbative regime.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

In this paper we continue our study of a class of Fokker-Planck-Alignment equations arising in collective dynamics,

$$
\partial_{t} f+v \cdot \nabla_{x} f=\sigma \mathrm{s}_{\rho} \Delta_{v} f+\nabla_{v} \cdot\left(\mathrm{~s}_{\rho}(v-[u]_{\rho}) f\right)
$$

We consider periodic-in- $x$ environment $\Omega=\mathbb{T}^{n}$, and $v \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$. Here, $\rho, \rho u$ are the macroscopic density and momentum, respectively; $s_{\rho}: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$is a uniformly bounded function called communication strength, and $[u]_{\rho}$ is a family of order preserving operators mapping $L_{\rho}^{\infty} \rightarrow L_{\rho}^{\infty}$ and $[1]_{\rho}=1$. A typical form of the operator includes a density-weighted averaging, such as Favre filtration, and for that reason we call them environmental averaging.

Equation (1) appears as a kinetic description of the large crowd limit $N \rightarrow \infty$ for solutions of the stochastic agent-based system, see [BCnC11, Shv24a],

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} x_{i} & =v_{i} \mathrm{~d} t \\
\mathrm{~d} v_{i} & =\mathrm{s}_{i}\left([v]_{i}-v_{i}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\sqrt{2 \sigma \mathrm{~s}_{i}} \mathrm{~d} B_{i}
\end{aligned} \quad i=1, \ldots, N
$$

where $B_{i}$ 's are independent Brownian motions in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, and the alignment force represents the discrete analogue of the above based on the empirical feed

$$
\rho^{N}=\sum_{i=1}^{N} m_{i} \delta_{x_{i}}, \quad u^{N}=\sum_{i=1}^{N} v_{i} \mathbb{1}_{x_{i}}
$$

The classical example of a system that falls under the class (2) was introduced (without noise) by Cucker and Smale in [CS07a, CS07b]

$$
\mathrm{s}_{\rho}=\rho * \phi, \quad[u]_{\rho}=\frac{(u \rho) * \phi}{\rho * \phi}
$$

Here, $\phi: \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$is a radially symmetric decreasing smooth kernel, and we denote for short $f_{\phi}=f * \phi$, and $\phi$ is assumed to be infinitely smooth. Unraveling the notation, the deterministic system is given by

$$
\dot{x}_{i}=v_{i}, \quad \dot{v}_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{N} m_{j} \phi\left(x_{i}-x_{j}\right)\left(v_{j}-v_{i}\right)
$$

Since its inception the Cucker-Smale system has been the focus of numerous studies with applications to swarming, satellite navigation, control, etc, see accounts [ABF+19, Axe97, BN05, EK01, PEG09, VZ12, MT14, MP18, Shv21, Tad21]. The system owes its success to predictability of alignment outcome based only on the properties of the kernel, and not perpetual assumptions on the flock such as connectivity or thickness. More precisely the following theorem holds.

Theorem 1.1 ([CS07a, CS07b, HT08, HL09]). If the kernel is fat tail, $\int_{0}^{\infty} \phi(r) d r=\infty$, then solutions to (4) align exponentially fast to the conserved mean velocity $\bar{v}=\frac{1}{\sum_{j=1}^{N} m_{j}} \sum_{j=1}^{N} m_{j} v_{j}$, while the flock remains bounded

$$
\max _{i=1, \ldots, N}\left|v_{i}-\bar{v}\right| \leqslant C e^{-\delta t}, \quad \max _{i, j=1, \ldots, N}\left|x_{i}-x_{j}\right| \leqslant \bar{D}
$$

where $C, \delta, \bar{D}$ depend only on the initial condition and parameters of the kernel.
The kinetic and macroscopic analogues of this theorem were established in [CFRT10, TT14], respectively.
Many variants of the Cucker-Smale model were introduced to address issues related to specific modeling scenarios. Among the earlier ones is the Motsch-Tadmor model, [MT11, MT14], given by
$\left(\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}\right)$

$$
\mathrm{s}_{\rho}=1, \quad[u]_{\rho}=\frac{(u \rho) * \phi}{\rho * \phi}
$$

Unlike $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}$, the model prescribes a pure density-weighted averaging protocol $[\cdot]_{\rho}$, also called Favre filtration [Fav83], which allows to calibrate the balance of forces between clusters of vastly different masses. The model, however is a-symmetric which is part of the reason for the lack of developed well-posedness analysis for it.

One can consider a range of interpolated models between $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}$ and $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}$, called $\beta$-models,

$$
\mathrm{s}_{\rho}=(\rho * \phi)^{\beta}, \quad[u]_{\rho}=\frac{(u \rho) * \phi}{\rho * \phi}, \quad \beta \geqslant 0
$$

A symmetric version of the $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}$-model was implemented in [Shv22] in the study of relaxation and hydrodynamic limit: assuming $\phi \in C^{\infty}$ and $\int \phi \mathrm{d} x=1$,

$$
\mathrm{s}_{\rho}=1, \quad[u]_{\rho}=\left(\frac{(u \rho) * \phi}{\rho * \phi}\right) * \phi
$$

Multi-flock and multi-species variants of the Cucker-Smale model were discussed in [HT17, ST21]. Topological interactions introduced in [ST20] can be also put in the same context if properly desingularized, see [Shv24a].

Another core example of a non-Galilean invariant system was introduced in [Shv24a] as a model of consensus formation in segregated communities. Consider a smooth partition of unity $g_{l} \in C^{\infty}(\Omega), g_{l} \geqslant 0$, and $\sum_{l=1}^{L} g_{l}=1$ subordinated to an open cover $\left\{\mathcal{O}_{l}\right\}_{l=1}^{L}$ of $\Omega$, so that supp $g_{l} \subset \mathcal{O}_{l}$. One defines the model by setting
$\left(\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}\right)$

$$
\mathrm{s}_{\rho}=1, \quad[u]_{\rho}(x)=\sum_{l=1}^{L} g_{l}(x) \frac{\int_{\Omega} u g_{l} \rho \mathrm{~d} y}{\int_{\Omega} g_{l} \rho \mathrm{~d} y}
$$

The noise included in (2) is not only a standard attribute of many agent-based models of swarming, but it also serves as a natural mechanism to break so called locked states that may occur in dynamics under local communication. Let us elaborate more on the latter point.

Systems of Cucker-Smale type present a viable setting for the study of emergence. Emergence is the problem of finding collective outcomes when communication between agents, in contrast to the assumptions of Theorem 1.1, is properly local, $\mathbb{1}_{r<r_{0}} \lesssim \phi(r) \lesssim \mathbb{1}_{r<r_{1}}$. The periodic environment $\mathbb{T}^{n}$ is a mathematically convenient way to focus on dynamics in the 'bulk' of the flock away from its boundaries. So, for any of the systems based on Favre filtration, if $r_{1}$ is small enough, there are natural counterexamples to alignment a pair of agents may evolve on parallel geodesic orbits with different velocities and without ever coming to contact within the radius. Any other configuration of agents with rationally dependent velocities $v_{i}$ may result in a similar locked solution. However, such solutions form a measure zero set in the configuration space $\left(\mathbb{T}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)^{N}$, and hence, are unlikely to be observed, see [Shv24b] for more on this.

In the context of stochastically forced systems the locked states will be disrupted by the noise, and the problem of emergence becomes the problem of relaxation to the corresponding equilibrium $\mu$. For the model (1), with thermalization proportional to $s_{\rho}$, such equilibria are given by the global Maxwellians,

$$
\mu_{\sigma, \bar{u}}=\frac{1}{|\Omega|(2 \pi \sigma)^{n / 2}} e^{-\frac{(v-\bar{u})^{2}}{2 \sigma}}, \quad \bar{u} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}
$$

So, the problem of emergence $f \rightarrow \mu_{\sigma, \bar{u}}$ becomes accessible by the methods of hypercoercivity, see [Vil09]. When $f$ is already close to $\mu_{\sigma, \bar{u}}$ initially in the sense that $g=\left(f-\mu_{\sigma, \bar{u}}\right) / \sqrt{\mu_{\sigma, \bar{u}}}$ is small in a higher order Sobolev metric, the relaxation was established by Duan et al [DFT10]. For the model with purely local alignment force $\nabla_{v}((v-u) f)$ and $s_{\rho} \equiv 1$ the same result was proved in [Cho16]. In the perturbative regime the system avoids two problems - degeneracy of the strength $s_{\rho}$ as a thermalization parameter in (1), and regularity of the macroscopic $u$. The first non-perturbative result was established in [Shv22] for the $\mathcal{M}_{\phi^{-}}$ model under the assumption that $u$ remains uniformly bounded for all times. And finally, in [Shv24a] the unconditional relaxation was proved for any smooth solution to (1) based on the classical Cucker-Smale model with a Bochner-positive kernel $\phi=\psi * \psi$; while for $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}$-model and more generally for $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$-models the result still holds for perturbative data but in the much weaker sense of small Fisher information.

In light of these developments it has become imperative to develop a consistent well-posedness theory for the Fokker-Planck-Alignment models (1) away from equilibrium. The first such result was presented for the Cucker-Smale-based model with constant diffusion coefficient, $\sigma \Delta_{v} f$, by Bolley, Cañizo, and Carrillo in [BCnC11], for measure-valued solutions with sub-Maxwellian decay, $\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} e^{a|v|^{2}} f \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x<\infty$. Karper, Mellet, and Trivisa [KMT13] prove existence of weak solutions with data in $f \in L^{1}\left(1+|v|^{2}+|x|^{2}\right) \cap L^{\infty}$ satisfying entropy inequality, and the result carries over to the $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}$-case also. The regularity of obtained solutions, however, is insufficient to carry out hypocoercivity analysis, and non of the previous studies attempted to address the hypoelliptic regularization in the context of Fokker-Planck-Alignment models. It should be noted, however, that Hölder-based regularization for models similar to (1) with no alignment but thermalization parameter depending on the density $\rho$ have been established in [AZ24, IM21]. Their approach relies on availability of an a priori $L^{\infty}$-control on the distribution $h=f / \mu \in L^{\infty}$, which in the presence of alignment fails to be the case.

The theory of classical solutions suitable for relaxation analysis was started in the same works [Shv22, Shv24a]. We developed global well-posedness in properly weighted Sobolev spaces for models of general type (1) starting from "thick" initial data, meaning data with the ball-averages of the density bounded from below

$$
\inf _{x \in \Omega} \int_{|y-x|<r_{0}} \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y>c_{0}
$$

Here, $r_{0}$ is the minimal radius of communication encoded in the environmental averaging $[u]_{\rho}$. It was observed in [Shv24a] that the proper formulation of Sobolev regularity compatible with the non-homogeneous FokkerPlanck operator in (1) must incorporate regressive weights:

$$
H_{q}^{m}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)=\left\{f: \sum_{2|\mathbf{k}|+|\mathbf{l}| \leqslant 2 m} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\langle v\rangle^{q-2|\mathbf{k}|-|\mathbf{l}|}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x<\infty\right\}
$$

If $q, m$ are large enough, the $H_{q}^{m}$-metric controls various information functionals needed in the hypocoercivity estimates, see [TV00], and consequently the result of [Shv24a] applies to establish exponential relaxation

$$
\left\|f(t)-\mu_{\sigma, \tilde{u}}\right\|_{L^{1}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \lesssim \sigma^{-1 / 2} e^{-c \sigma t}
$$

for any classical solutions in $H_{q}^{m}$ for the following models:

- the Cucker-Smale model $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}$ with a Bochner-positive kernel $\phi=\psi * \psi$;
- the $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$-model with $\inf \phi>0$;
- the segregation model $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$ with $\operatorname{supp} g_{l}=\Omega$ for all $l=1, \ldots, L$.
- the non-symmetric models $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}, \mathcal{M}_{\beta}$, with $\phi=\psi * \psi$, and $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}, \mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$ without any restrictions, provided

$$
\mathcal{I}\left(f_{0}\right)=\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\left|\sigma \nabla_{v} f_{0}+v f_{0}\right|^{2}}{f} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \leqslant \delta \sigma
$$

for some small $\delta>0$ depending only on the parameters of the model.
For general data Sobolev settings are too restrictive even for local well-posedness. So, a suitable formulation of solutions for such data would be on the distributional level as in [BCnC11, KMT13]. Such solutions, however, lack the regularity needed for the analysis of long time behavior. The main purpose of this paper is to develop an existence theory that comes together with the hypoelliptic regularization and relaxation. For many models, including the original Cucker-Smale based Fokker-Planck-Alignment equation, the theory gives a complete description of the dynamics from an arbitrary vacuous data, see Theorem 1.2 below.

Let us point out the main technical issues. First and foremost, thin data yields a degenerate diffusion coefficient $\mathrm{s}_{p}$, which meddles with the hypoellipticity of the equation. Second, the regularity of weak solutions provided by the Fisher information, $\mathrm{s}_{p} \frac{\left|\nabla_{v} f\right|^{2}}{f} \in L_{t, x, v}^{1}$, is in insufficient for the application of classical techniques such as comparison principle. To circumvent these issues we show that weak solutions are automatically renormalized in the sense of DiPerna-Lions, and as a consequence satisfy the entropy equality from time $t=0$, as well as a weak maximum principle, see Lemma 3.6. Incidentally, the Fisher information plays the same role of critical regularity for the entropy law as Onsager- $1 / 3$ regularity for the energy conservation in incompressible fluids, see [Ise18, ES06, DLS09, CET94, CCFS08] and references therein. The problem of degeneracy of the Fisher information, however, is the main technical difficulty that prevents the use of such regularity directly. We therefore implement a new approach based on considering evolution of a thickness-weighted mollification, $\frac{\left|\theta f\right|_{t_{1}}}{\theta+\varepsilon_{2}}$, where $\theta$ is the thickness of the flock, see (15), (80), and $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0$ are small parameters. Formally, if $\varepsilon_{1}=\varepsilon_{2}=0$, this restores the original solution, however, in the intermediate estimates on the flux terms, by considering such mollification, we gain direct access to the a priori known Fisher-regularity of $\theta f$.

With the renormalization at hand, we can apply the spread of positivity result of [Shv24a, Proposition $7.3]$ to show gain of Gaussian tails,

$$
f(t, x, v) \geqslant b e^{-a|v|^{2}}, \quad \forall(t, x, v) \in \mathbb{T}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \times[\varepsilon, \infty)
$$

Thus, the solution becomes non-vacuous, which makes coefficients involved in (1) smooth. This subsequently opens access to a global hypoelliptic regularization, which we prove in Theorem 5.1.

In the next section we describe full statements of the results which apply to all core models - some unconditionally, some with additional assumptions on the kernel or data. The classical Cucker-Smale model happens to require the fewest assumptions as it pertains to the averaging protocol itself. So, in this case we can complete the description of dynamics starting from any data. Let us summarize the result here.

Theorem 1.2. Consider the Fokker-Planck-Alignment equation (1) based on the Cucker-Smale averaging protocol $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}$ with a Bochner-positive kernel $\phi=\psi * \psi$. For any data $f_{0} \in L^{\infty} \cap L^{1},|v|^{2} f_{0} \in L^{1},|v|^{q} f_{0} \in L^{2}$, $q \geqslant 2$, there exists a global weak solution in the same class and with finite Fisher information $\mathrm{s}_{p} \frac{\left|\nabla_{v} f\right|^{2}}{f} \in$ $L_{t, x, v}^{1}$, satisfying the entropy law (37). Every such solution gains uniform Gaussian tails (9) and regularizes into $H_{q}^{m}$ for any $m \in \mathbb{N}$ instantly. If $q$ is large enough, then solutions are unique from thick data, and every solution relaxes to the Maxwellian exponentially fast,

$$
\left\|f(t)-\mu_{\sigma, \tilde{u}_{0}}\right\|_{L^{1}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leqslant c_{1} \sigma^{-1 / 2} e^{-c_{2} \sigma t}
$$

# 2. EnVIRONMENTAL AVERAGING MODELS, DESCRIPTION OF THE RESULTS 

In this section we give detailed description of our results. Following [Shv24a], we adopt the framework of environmental averaging models, which encompasses all the examples introduced above, and allows us to state results more generally.
2.1. Environmental averaging models and their regularity. Let $\Omega=\mathbb{T}^{n}$. Denote by $\mathcal{P}(\Omega)$ the set of probability measures on $\Omega$. An environmental averaging model is a family of pairs

$$
\mathcal{M}=\left\{\left(\mathrm{s}_{\rho},\left[\cdot\right]_{\rho}\right): \rho \in \mathcal{P}(\Omega)\right\}
$$

where $\mathrm{s}_{\rho}: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}, \mathrm{s}_{\rho} \in C(\Omega)$, represents a (specific) scalar communication strength, and $\left[\cdot\right]_{\rho}$ is a family of order-preserving bounded linear operators on weighted $L_{\rho}^{\infty}$ spaces with $[1]_{\rho}=1$. Many of the axiomatic properties listed in the original work [Shv24a] will be automatically satisfied in the specific class of models adopted here. Namely, we consider models where the weighted averages

$$
\mathrm{w}_{\rho}(u)=\mathrm{s}_{\rho}[u]_{\rho}
$$

are given in the form of a bounded integral operator

$$
\mathrm{w}_{\rho}(u)=\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho}(x, y) u(y) \mathrm{d} \rho(y), \quad \rho \text {-a.e. }
$$

represented by a non-negative communication kernel $\phi_{\rho} \in L^{1}(\mathrm{~d} \rho \otimes \mathrm{d} \rho), \rho \in \mathcal{P}$, satisfying

$$
\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho}(x, y) \mathrm{d} \rho(y)=\mathrm{s}_{\rho}(x), \quad \rho \text {-a.e. }
$$

All our core models have explicit formulas for their kernels stated in Table 1.
It is very convenient to formulate regularity and mapping properties of a model $\mathcal{M}$ directly in terms of its strength $\mathrm{s}_{\rho}$ and kernel $\phi_{\rho}$. In particular, we assume that our models are local, meaning that agents always interact within some radius $r_{0}>0$, called radius of communication:

$$
\phi_{\rho}(x, y) \geqslant c_{0}, \text { for all }|x-y|<r_{0}, \text { and all } \rho \in \mathcal{P}(\Omega)
$$

Further conditions involve the concept of thickness, which is defined here as the mass of a flock in a local neighborhood,

$$
\theta(\rho, x)=\int_{\Omega} \rho\left(x-r_{0} y\right) \chi(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

where $\chi \in C_{0}^{\infty}$ is a standard radially symmetric mollifier supported on the unit ball. We also define the global thickness as

$$
\theta(\rho, \Omega)=\inf _{x \in \Omega} \theta(\rho, x)
$$

Basic conditions on the strength are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{\rho \in \mathcal{P}(\Omega)}\left\|\mathrm{s}_{\rho}\right\|_{\infty} \leqslant \bar{S} \\
& \rho \rightarrow \mathrm{~s}_{\rho} \text { is continuous from } L^{1}(\Omega) \text { to } L^{\infty}(\Omega) \\
& \mathrm{s}_{\rho}(x) \geqslant c \theta(\rho, x) \quad \text { for all } x \in \Omega
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we state the list of basic regularity assumptions for uniformly thick flocks. These are necessary to develop a local well-posedness theory for classical thick data.

Definition 2.1. We say that a model $\mathcal{M}$ is regular if in addition to the above it meets the following set of conditions: for all $\rho, \rho^{\prime}, \rho^{\prime \prime} \in L^{1}(\Omega)$ we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\partial_{x}^{k} \mathrm{~s}_{\rho}\right\|_{\infty}+\left\|\partial_{x}^{k} \phi_{\rho}\right\|_{\infty}+\left\|\partial_{y}^{k} \phi_{\rho}\right\|_{\infty} \leqslant C_{k}(\theta(\rho, \Omega)), \quad k=0,1, \ldots \\
\left\|\mathrm{~s}_{\rho^{\prime}}-\mathrm{s}_{\rho^{\prime \prime}}\right\|_{\infty}+\left\|\phi_{\rho^{\prime}}-\phi_{\rho^{\prime \prime}}\right\|_{\infty} \leqslant C\left(\theta\left(\rho^{\prime}, \Omega\right), \theta\left(\rho^{\prime \prime}, \Omega\right)\right)\left\|\rho^{\prime}-\rho^{\prime \prime}\right\|_{1}
\end{gathered}
$$

Remark 2.2. This definition differs from one used in [Shv24a] in only one detail - the Lipschitzness assumption (20) was stated in terms of the Wasserstein distance $W_{1}\left(\rho^{\prime}, \rho^{\prime \prime}\right)$. The use of the weaker metric was necessary to carry out the mean-field limit and well-posedness of the corresponding discrete model. For our purposes here, the strong metric is sufficient, although it is obvious that all our core models are regular in the stronger sense of the definition stated in [Shv24a].
Theorem 2.3 ([Shv24a]). Suppose that the model $\mathcal{M}$ is regular. Let $f_{0} \in H_{q}^{m}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right), q, m \geqslant n+3$, be a uniformly thick initial condition,

$$
\theta\left(\rho_{0}, \Omega\right)>0
$$

Then there exists a unique local solution to (1) on a time interval $[0, T)$ in the regularity class

$$
f \in C_{w}\left([0, T) ; H_{q}^{m}\right), \quad \nabla_{v} f \in L^{2}\left([0, T] ; H_{q}^{m}\right)
$$

Here, $T>0$ depends only on the initial energy $\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|v|^{2} f_{0} d v d x$ and thickness $\theta\left(\rho_{0}, \Omega\right)$.
Moreover, if $f \in L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; H_{q}^{m}\right)$ is a given solution such that

$$
\inf _{[0, T)} \theta(\rho, \Omega)>0
$$

then $f$ can be extended to an interval $[0, T+\varepsilon)$ in the same class.
Remark 2.4. Many models possess a native thickness $\Theta(\rho, x)$, relative to which they are regular. For example, for all $\mathcal{M}_{\beta}$-models and the $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$-model it is natural to define $\Theta(\rho, x)=\rho * \phi$. The segregation model is regular relative to

$$
\Theta(\rho, x)=\min _{l: x \in \operatorname{supp} g_{l}} \rho\left(g_{l}\right)
$$

In all these cases $\Theta(\rho, x) \geqslant c \theta(\rho, x)$, which on the one hand makes our notion of thickness $\theta$ universal, but at the same time makes it harder for a flock to be $\theta$-thick rather than natively $\Theta$-thick. In particular, Theorem 2.3 would impose less stringent requirement on data if stated in terms of $\Theta$. In [Shv24a] we formulated a set of conditions on $\Theta$ which allow to prove such a native version of Theorem 2.3. However, for our purposes here, where Theorem 2.3 will only be used as an intermediate step to get solutions for non-vacuous data, the choice of using generic $\theta$ will be sufficient.

To construct weak solutions from any data, a model needs to meet certain criteria that do not depend on thickness. As far as the strength-function is concerned, our basic assumptions of boundedness (16) and continuity-in- $\rho$ (17) are already sufficient. For the communication kernel, we assume that the family is uniformly in Schur's class

$$
\overline{S r}=\sup _{\rho \in \mathcal{P}}\left\|\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho}(x, \cdot) \mathrm{d} \rho(x)\right\|_{\infty}<\infty
$$

and the corresponding continuity-in- $\rho$ condition is stated as follows: for any sequence of densities $\rho_{n} \rightarrow \rho$ in $L^{1}$, and any subordinate sequence $\left|\tilde{\rho}_{n}\right| \leqslant C \rho_{n},|\tilde{\rho}| \leqslant C \rho$, with $\tilde{\rho}_{n} \rightarrow \tilde{\rho}$ in $L^{1}$, one has

$$
\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho_{n}}(x, \cdot) \tilde{\rho}_{n}(x) \mathrm{d} x \rightarrow \int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho}(x, \cdot) \tilde{\rho}(x) \mathrm{d} x, \text { weakly* in } L_{\rho}^{\infty}
$$

Let note that (24) together with the corresponding symmetric condition in $y$, which is automatically satisfied due to (13) and (16), form a set of classical Schur's conditions. Kernels in Schur's class define operators bounded on any $L_{y}^{p}, 1 \leqslant p \leqslant \infty$. In our terms, it implies that the energy of weighted averages are bounded by the macroscopic energy:

$$
\left\|\mathrm{w}_{\rho}(u)\right\|_{L_{y}^{q}} \leqslant(\overline{S r} \bar{S})^{1 / 2}\|u\|_{L_{y}^{q}}
$$

For future reference we make the following definition.
Definition 2.5. A regular model satisfying (24)-(25) is said to belong to Schur's class.

Lemma 2.6. All models $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}, \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}, \mathcal{M}_{\beta}, \mathcal{M}_{\phi}, \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{seg}}$ are regular of Schur's class.
Proof. First, we already noted that all models are trivially regular. Let us focus on Schur's conditions. The boundedness (24) follows immediately from (13) and (16) for all symmetric models,

$$
\phi_{\rho}(x, y)=\phi_{\rho}(y, x)
$$

Those include $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}, \mathcal{M}_{\phi}$, and $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$ from our list. We regard to $\mathcal{M}_{\beta}$, including the Motsch-Tadmor model $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}$, condition (24) reduces to showing that the expression $\left(\frac{\rho}{(\rho * \phi)^{1-\beta}}\right) * \phi$ is uniformly bounded in $L^{\infty}$ and over all $\rho \in \mathcal{P}$. This follows from a more precise bound proved in [Shv24a], and [KMT13] in the case $\beta=0$,

$$
\left(\frac{\rho}{(\rho * \phi)^{1-\beta}}\right) * \phi \leqslant C(\rho * \phi)^{\beta}, \quad \forall 0 \leqslant \beta \leqslant 1
$$

Condition (25) is trivial for the $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}$-model, and for others it is somewhat more involved. Let us break it down by models.

Let us verify (25) for the $\mathcal{M}_{\beta}$-models, $0 \leqslant \beta<1$. Let us fix a test function $g \in L_{\rho}^{1}$ and notice the following uniform continuity: for any $\varepsilon>0$ there exists a $\delta>0$ such that whenever $\rho * \phi(x)<\delta$, then $(g \rho) * \phi(x)<\varepsilon$. Indeed, otherwise, there exists a sequence $x_{n} \in \Omega$ such that $\rho * \phi\left(x_{n}\right)<1 / n$, yet $(g \rho) * \phi\left(x_{n}\right) \geqslant \varepsilon_{0}$. By compactness, $x_{n} \rightarrow x_{0}$, and by continuity $\rho * \phi\left(x_{0}\right)=0$, yet $(g \rho) * \phi\left(x_{0}\right) \geqslant \varepsilon_{0}$, a contradiction. So, for any $\varepsilon>0$ let us pick $\delta>0$ as above, and compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega}\left(\phi_{\rho_{n}}(x, y) \tilde{\rho}_{n}(x)-\phi_{\rho}(x, y) \tilde{\rho}(x)\right) \mathrm{d} x g(y) \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y & =\int_{\Omega}\left(\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{n}(x)}{\rho_{n} * \phi(x)}-\frac{\tilde{\rho}(x)}{\rho * \phi(x)}\right)(g \rho) * \phi(x) \mathrm{d} x \\
& =\int_{\rho * \phi \geqslant \delta}\left(\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{n}(x)}{\rho_{n} * \phi(x)}-\frac{\tilde{\rho}(x)}{\rho * \phi(x)}\right)(g \rho) * \phi(x) \mathrm{d} x \\
& +\int_{\rho * \phi<\delta}\left(\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{n}(x)}{\rho_{n} * \phi(x)}-\frac{\tilde{\rho}(x)}{\rho * \phi(x)}\right)(g \rho) * \phi(x) \mathrm{d} x:=I+I I
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that since $\rho_{n} \rightarrow \rho$ in $L^{1}$, starting from some $n$, we will have $\rho_{n} * \phi \geqslant \delta / 2$ in the first integral. It is clear then that $I \rightarrow 0$. For $I I$ we have

$$
|I I| \leqslant C \varepsilon \int_{\Omega}\left(\frac{\rho_{n}(x)}{\rho_{n} * \phi(x)}+\frac{\rho(x)}{\rho * \phi(x)}\right) \mathrm{d} x
$$

It remains to prove that

$$
\sup _{\rho \in L^{1}} \int_{\Omega} \frac{\rho(x)}{\rho * \phi(x)} \mathrm{d} x<\infty
$$

This is in fact related to (28), and goes by the same proof, but since we will be using it over again later, let us present a short argument. In fact, in view of the locality of the kernel $\phi$, it follows from

$$
\sup _{\rho \in L^{1}} \int_{\Omega} \frac{\rho(x)}{\theta(\rho, x)} \mathrm{d} x<\infty
$$

Let us recall that the mollifier used to define $\theta$ is bounded from below on the ball of radius $r_{0} / 2$. So, $\theta(\rho, x) \gtrsim \int_{B_{r_{0} / 2}(x)} \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y$. Now by a standard covering, there exist $J$ balls, where $J$ depends only on $n$ and $r_{0}$ such that $\Omega \subset \cup_{j=1}^{J} B_{r_{0} / 4}\left(x_{j}\right)$. Then, since for all $x \in B_{r_{0} / 4}\left(x_{j}\right), B_{r_{0} / 4}\left(x_{j}\right) \subset B_{r_{0} / 2}(x)$,

$$
\int_{\Omega} \frac{\rho(x)}{\theta(\rho, x)} \mathrm{d} x \lesssim \sum_{j=1}^{J} \int_{B_{r_{0} / 4}\left(x_{j}\right)} \frac{\rho(x)}{\int_{B_{r_{0} / 2}(x)} \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y} \mathrm{~d} x \leqslant \sum_{j=1}^{J} \int_{B_{r_{0} / 4}\left(x_{j}\right)} \frac{\rho(x)}{\int_{B_{r_{0} / 4}\left(x_{j}\right)} \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y} \mathrm{~d} x=J
$$

Thus, $\int_{\Omega} \frac{\rho(x)}{\theta(\rho, x)} \mathrm{d} x \lesssim J$. This proves (30), which implies that $|I I| \leqslant C \varepsilon$, and consequently, (25).

Let us verify (25) for the $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$-model. Switching convolutions with the kernel $\phi$ twice we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega}\left(\phi_{\rho_{n}}(x, y) \tilde{\rho}_{n}(x)-\phi_{\rho}(x, y) \tilde{\rho}(x)\right) \mathrm{d} x g(y) \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y & =\int_{\Omega}\left(\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{n} * \phi}{\rho_{n} * \phi}-\frac{\tilde{\rho} * \phi}{\rho * \phi}\right)(g \rho) * \phi \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =\int_{\rho * \phi \geqslant \delta}\left(\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{n} * \phi}{\rho_{n} * \phi}-\frac{\tilde{\rho} * \phi}{\rho * \phi}\right)(g \rho) * \phi \mathrm{~d} x \\
& +\int_{\rho * \phi<\delta}\left(\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{n} * \phi}{\rho_{n} * \phi}-\frac{\tilde{\rho} * \phi}{\rho * \phi}\right)(g \rho) * \phi \mathrm{~d} x:=I+I I
\end{aligned}
$$

As before $I \rightarrow 0$ trivially, and $|I I| \lesssim \varepsilon$ simply by the subordination of the tilda-sequence.
Lastly, let us verify (25) for the $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$-model.

$$
\int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega}\left(\phi_{\rho_{n}}(x, y) \tilde{\rho}_{n}(x)-\phi_{\rho}(x, y) \tilde{\rho}(x)\right) \mathrm{d} x g(y) \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y=\sum_{l=1}^{L}\left(\frac{\int_{\Omega} \tilde{\rho}_{n} g_{l} \mathrm{~d} x}{\int_{\Omega} \rho_{n} g_{l} \mathrm{~d} z}-\frac{\int_{\Omega} \tilde{\rho} g_{l} \mathrm{~d} x}{\int_{\Omega} \rho g_{l} \mathrm{~d} z}\right) \int_{\Omega} g_{l}(y) g(y) \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

Note that by the subordination the coefficients in the sum are all bounded. Now, if for an $l \leqslant L, \int_{\Omega} \rho g_{l} \mathrm{~d} z=$ $\delta>0$, then $\int_{\Omega} \rho_{n} g_{l} \mathrm{~d} z \geqslant \delta / 2$ starting from some $n$, the that term clearly vanishes in the limit as $n \rightarrow \infty$. If $\int_{\Omega} \rho g_{l} \mathrm{~d} z=0$, then $\int_{\Omega} g_{l}(y) g(y) \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y=0$, and consequently that term is missing from the sum. This concludes the proof.

Remark 2.7. As a side note we mention that the same $L^{2}$-boundedness (26) holds for Hilbert-Schmidt kernels

$$
\sup _{\rho \in \mathcal{P}} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho}^{2}(x, y) \mathrm{d} \rho(y) \mathrm{d} \rho(x)<\infty
$$

One can in principle construct an alternative well-posedness theory based on conditions of Hilbert-Schmidt type, for example, by requiring

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sup _{y \in \Omega, \rho \in \mathcal{P}(\Omega)}\left|\phi_{\rho}(x, y)\right| \leqslant C(\theta(\rho, x)) \\
\int_{\Omega} \int_{\theta(\rho, x) \geqslant \delta}\left|\phi_{\rho}(x, y)-\phi_{\rho_{n}}(x, y)\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \rho_{n}(x) \mathrm{d} \rho_{n}(y) \rightarrow 0, \text { as }\left\|\rho-\rho_{n}\right\|_{1} \rightarrow 0
\end{gathered}
$$

in place of (24) - (25). In our situation this approach appears to be less inclusive as it does not apply to the thickness-nonlocal $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$-model. Still it is worth noting that the Hilbert-Schmidt condition itself (31) holds for all our core models and plays a crucial role in establishing hydrodynamic limits passing from kinetic to macroscopic description, see [Shv24a, KMT15].
2.2. Existence of weak solutions for regular models of Schur's class. Let us now state our first main result. We use the following notation for weighted Lebesgue spaces

$$
L_{q}^{p}:=\left\{f: \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\langle v\rangle^{q} f^{p} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x<\infty\right\}, \quad\langle v\rangle=\left(1+|v|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

Definition 2.8. We say that

$$
f \in L^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}\right) \cap C\left([0, T) ; \mathcal{D}^{\prime}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)\right)
$$

is a weak solution to (1) with initial condition $f_{0}$ if for every $\varphi \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left([0, T) \times \Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ one has

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{T} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} & \partial_{t} \varphi f \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} t+\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \varphi(0, x, v) f_{0} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x+\int_{0}^{T} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} v \cdot \nabla_{x} \varphi f \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =-\int_{0}^{T} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} s_{\rho} f \Delta_{v} \varphi \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} t+\int_{0}^{T} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} s_{\rho}\left(v-[u]_{\rho}\right) f \cdot \nabla_{v} \varphi \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

Let us remark that solutions in the regularity class (34) automatically belong to a range of $L \log L$-classes.
Lemma 2.9. Let $1 \leqslant p<\infty$ and $0 \leqslant \gamma<2$, then $|v|^{\gamma} f|\log f|^{p} \in L_{t}^{\infty} L_{x, v}^{1}$.

Proof. Indeed,

$$
|v|^{\gamma} \mathbb{1}_{f \geqslant 1} f \log ^{p} f \leqslant\langle v\rangle^{2} f \log _{v}^{p}\left(\|f\|_{\infty}\right) \in L_{t}^{\infty} L_{x, v}^{1}
$$

while

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |v|^{\gamma} \mathbb{1}_{f \leqslant 1} f(-\log f)^{p}=|v|^{\gamma} \mathbb{1}_{f \leqslant \exp \left(-|v|^{\frac{2-\gamma}{p}}\right)} f(-\log f)^{p}+|v|^{\gamma} \mathbb{1}_{\exp \left(-|v|^{\frac{2-\gamma}{p}}\right)<f \leqslant 1} f(-\log f)^{p} \\
& \leqslant c|v|^{\gamma} \mathbb{1}_{f \leqslant \exp \left(-|v|^{\frac{2-\gamma}{p}}\right)} \sqrt{f}+f|v|^{2} \leqslant|v|^{\gamma} \exp \left(-|v|^{\frac{2-\gamma}{p}}\right)+f|v|^{2} \in L_{t}^{\infty} L_{x, v}^{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 2.10. Let $\mathcal{M}$ be a regular model of Schur's class.
Existence: For any initial condition $f_{0} \in L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}$ there exists a global weak solution to (1) in the class

$$
f \in L^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}\right) \cap C\left([0, T) ; \mathcal{D}^{\prime}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)\right), \quad s_{\rho} \frac{\left|\nabla_{v} f\right|^{2}}{f} \in L^{1}\left([0, T) \times \Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)
$$

for any $T>0$.
Entropy: Any weak solution in the above class satisfies the entropy equality

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{H} & =\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} f \log f d v d x+\frac{1}{2} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|v|^{2} f d v d x \\
\mathcal{H}(t)-\mathcal{H}(0) & =-\int_{0}^{t} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} s_{\rho} \frac{\left|\nabla_{v} f+v f\right|^{2}}{f} d v d x d s+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\mathrm{w}_{\rho}(u), u\right)_{\rho} d s
\end{aligned}
$$

Renormalization: any weak solution is automatically renormalized in the sense of DiPerna-Lions, see Proposition 3.1.

Uniqueness: Let $f^{\prime}, f^{\prime \prime}$ be two weak solutions in class (36) with $f_{0}^{\prime}=f_{0}^{\prime \prime} \in L_{q}^{2}, q \geqslant n+4$, and $\theta\left(\rho^{\prime}, \Omega\right)>0$ on $[0, T)$. Then $f^{\prime}=f^{\prime \prime}$ on $[0, T)$.

Higher moments: If $f_{0} \in L_{q}^{1}$ for $q>2$, then in addition to (36) there exists a solution with $f \in$ $L^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; L_{q}^{1}\right)$, for any $T>0$.

As a consequence of Lemma 2.6, all models $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}, \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}, \mathcal{M}_{\beta}, \mathcal{M}_{\phi}, \mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$ fall under the range of Theorem 2.10. Let us note, however, that the result falls short in two details - it does not provide uniqueness for non-thick data, and the propagation of higher moments is not claimed for any given solution. Instead, we show that at least one such weak solution exists. To prove propagation requires boundedness of the drift $\mathrm{w}_{\rho}(u)$, see Theorem 4.1, which is not guaranteed for all models. This will be discussed in the next section.
2.3. Gain of positivity and parabolic regularization. Theorem 2.10 represents the best well-posedness result we can obtain under no additional assumptions on the model $\mathcal{M}$. Solutions to Fokker-Planck type equations are expected to gain more regularity due to the classical hypoelliptic interplay between the transport and diffusion terms. In our situation this result stumbles upon two issues - a possibly degenerate thermalization coefficient $s_{\rho}$, and lack of regularity of the drift $\mathrm{w}_{\rho}$. For regular models $\mathcal{M}$, both issues are resolved for thick flocks $\theta(\rho, \Omega)>0$ as readily seen from the assumptions (18), (19). So, the first step in proving regularization result consists in establishing gain of positivity for solutions of (1). The following result was proved in [Shv24a] for classical solutions, and we will show extend it to the class of weak solutions in Section 3.8.

Proposition 2.11. Let $\mathcal{M}$ be a regular model. For a given weak $f$ in class (36) on a time interval $[0, T)$ there exists $a, b>0$ which depend only on the parameters of the model $\mathcal{M}$, time $T$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{W}=\sup _{t \in[0, T)}\left\|\mathrm{w}_{\rho}(u)\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \bar{H}=\sup _{t \in[0, T)} \int_{\mathbb{T}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|v|^{2} f d v d x+\int_{\mathbb{T}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} f|\log f| d v d x
\end{aligned}
$$

such that

$$
f(t, x, v) \geqslant b e^{-a|v|^{2}}, \quad \forall(t, x, v) \in \mathbb{T}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \times[T / 2, T)
$$

Clearly the result applies instantaneously in time on $[\varepsilon, T)$, with $a, b$ being dependent on $\varepsilon, T$, and the Gaussian bound (39) makes the flock non-vacuous, and hence, thick. As a consequence of the regularity of $\mathcal{M}$, all the coefficients of the equation become smooth on $[0, T)$ and thermalization $\mathrm{s}_{\rho}$ strictly positive. This puts the model (1) within the applicability of the classical regularization theory. In Theorem 5.1 we stated a version of global hypoellipticity result that puts our solutions directly in the weighted Sobolev spaces $H_{q}^{m}$ as long as the data has finite $q$-moment $f_{0} \in L_{q}^{2}$. Since $f \in L^{\infty} L_{q}^{2}$, setting $f_{0}=f(\varepsilon)$ as initial condition, provides instantaneous regularization into $H_{2}^{m}$ for all $m \in \mathbb{N}$ with $\|f(t)\|_{H_{2}^{m}} \lesssim 1 /(t-\varepsilon)^{\kappa}$.

We thus conclude that regularization of solutions is based upon control over two key quantities (38). So, let us discuss the absolute entropy $\bar{H}$ first. For Schur's models, $\bar{H}$ remains bounded on any finite time interval. Indeed, due to the $L^{2}$-boundedness (26), we can see from the energy law (77) that $\mathcal{E}<C_{1}$ on $[0, T)$. Hence, from (37), $\mathcal{H}<C_{2}$ on $[0, T)$. By the classical inequality, [Lio94, GJV04], there is an absolute constant $C_{3}>0$ such that

$$
\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|f \log f| \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} x \leqslant \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} f \log f \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x+\frac{1}{4} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|v|^{2} f \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x+C_{3} \leqslant \mathcal{H}+C_{3}
$$

So,

$$
\bar{H} \leqslant 2 \mathcal{H}+C_{3}<C_{4}
$$

Thus, Schur's conditions are sufficient to control the absolute entropy $\bar{H}$.
As to the drift $\bar{W}$, we need to add it as an additional assumption on solution. Our most general regularization result can be stated as follows.

Theorem 2.12. Let $\mathcal{M}$ be a regular model of Schur's class. Then any weak solution $f$ to (1) in class (36) and with bounded drift, $\bar{W}<\infty$, gains instant regularization on $[\varepsilon, T)$ with

$$
\|f\|_{H_{2}^{m}} \leqslant C_{\varepsilon, T, m}, \quad \forall m \in \mathbb{N}
$$

If, in addition, $f_{0} \in L_{q}^{2}, q \geqslant 2$, then

$$
\|f\|_{H_{2}^{m}} \leqslant C_{\varepsilon, T, m}, \quad \forall m \in \mathbb{N}
$$

The second conclusion follows from the propagation of moments Theorem 4.1. It ensures that $f \in L^{\infty} L_{q}^{2}$ as long as $\bar{W}<\infty$, which results in (43) by Theorem 5.1.

For a narrower yet still extensive class of models the drift $\bar{W}$ is automatically controlled by the energy these are the models with uniform $L^{2}$-to- $L^{\infty}$ regularization property:

$$
\left\|\mathrm{w}_{\rho}(u)\right\|_{L_{\rho}^{\infty}} \leqslant C\|u\|_{L_{\rho}^{2}}
$$

with $C>0$ independent of $\rho \in L^{1}$. Conditions of this sort for general integral operators is a classical subject, see [Lev09] for a comprehensive overview. The boundedness between $L_{\rho}^{p} \rightarrow L_{\rho}^{q}$ holds for a class of kernels satisfying the following mixed Lebesgue integrability condition:

$$
\bar{F}_{p, q}=\sup _{\rho \in \mathcal{P}} \int_{\Omega}\left(\int_{\Omega} \phi_{p}^{*}(x, y) \mathrm{d} \rho(y)\right)^{q / p^{*}} \mathrm{~d} \rho(x)<\infty, \quad \frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{p^{*}}=1
$$

For the case in question, $p=2, q=\infty$, we obtain

$$
\bar{F}_{2, \infty}=\sup _{\rho \in \mathcal{P}}\left\|\int_{\Omega} \phi_{p}^{2}(\cdot, y) \mathrm{d} \rho(y)\right\|_{\infty}<\infty
$$

This is clearly satisfied for the Cucker-Smale model $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}$. More generally, in the range of $\mathcal{M}_{\beta}$-models, we have (44) satisfied only $\beta \geqslant \frac{1}{2}$. Indeed,

$$
\int_{\Omega}\left|\frac{\phi(x-y)}{(\rho * \phi)^{1-\beta}(x)}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \rho(y) \leqslant\|\phi\|_{\infty} \frac{\rho_{\phi}(x)}{(\rho * \phi)^{2-2 \beta}(x)}=\|\phi\|_{\infty}(\rho * \phi)^{2 \beta-1}(x) \leqslant\|\phi\|_{\infty}^{2 \beta}
$$

Among other core models, $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}, \mathcal{M}_{\phi}$, and $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$, condition (46) does not hold for general kernels, unless the kernel is global, i.e. if $\inf \phi>0$, or if $\operatorname{supp} g_{l}=\Omega$, for all $l \leqslant L$, for the $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$-model. Let us collect these observations as a corollary.
Corollary 2.13. The conclusions of Theorem 2.12 hold for any weak solution to (1) based on
(1) all the $\mathcal{M}_{\beta}$-models with $\beta \geqslant \frac{1}{2}$, and in particular, for the $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}$-model;

(2) all the $\mathcal{M}_{\beta}$-models with $\beta \geqslant 0$ including $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}$, and for $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$, provided $\inf \phi>0$;
(3) $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$, provided $\operatorname{supp} g_{l}=\Omega$, for all $l \leqslant L$.
2.4. Global relaxation. Relaxation of solutions starting from arbitrary data relies to two key factors. One is sufficient regularity of solutions to conduct the hypocercivity estimates, and in particular derive an equation on the total Fisher information

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{I} & =\mathcal{I}_{v v}+\mathcal{I}_{x x} \\
\mathcal{I}_{v v} & =\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\left|\sigma \nabla_{v} f+v f\right|^{2}}{f} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x, \quad \mathcal{I}_{x x}=\sigma \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\left|\nabla_{x} f\right|^{2}}{f} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x
\end{aligned}
$$

The Fisher information is controlled by $H_{q}^{m}$ if $m, q$ are large enough, [TV00, Lemma 1].
Second, the flock must maintain uniform thickness which by regularity of $\mathcal{M}$ implies smoothness of all the coefficients in (1), and must also maintain a uniform bound on the spectral gap of the averages. More precisely, let us recall the following result proved in [Shv24a].

Proposition 2.14. Suppose $\mathcal{M}$ is a regular model. Let $f \in H_{q}^{m}$ be a classical solution to (1) with density $\rho$ satisfying the following conditions uniformly in time
(i) $\theta(\rho, \Omega) \geqslant c_{0}$
(ii) there exists a constant $\varepsilon_{0}>0$ such that

$$
\sup _{\int u \rho d x=0} \frac{\left(u,[u]_{\rho}\right)_{\kappa_{\rho}}}{(u, u)_{\kappa_{\rho}}} \leqslant 1-\varepsilon_{0}, \quad \kappa_{\rho}=\mathrm{s}_{\rho} \rho
$$

Then $f$ relaxes to the corresponding Maxwellian exponentially fast,

$$
\left\|f(t)-\mu_{\sigma, \bar{u}(t)}\right\|_{L^{1}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leqslant c_{1} \sqrt{\sigma^{-1} \mathcal{I}\left(f_{0}\right)} e^{-c_{2} \sigma t}
$$

where $c_{1}, c_{2}>0$ depend only on the parameters of the model $\mathcal{M}$, and

$$
\bar{u}=\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} v f(t, x, v) d v d x
$$

Generally, the momentum $\bar{u}$ is not conserved, even though the result still holds. However, one can show that the momentum still settles exponentially fast $\bar{u} \rightarrow u_{\infty}$ for some $u_{\infty} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ for all our core models. Indeed, a general sufficient condition which holds for all of them was obtained in [Shv24a, Lemma 8.6]:

$$
\frac{1}{|\Omega|} \int_{\Omega} \phi_{\frac{1}{|\Omega|}}(x, y) \mathrm{d} x=\mathrm{s}_{\frac{1}{|\Omega|}}(y)
$$

Corollary 2.15. For all core models, $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}, \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}, \mathcal{M}_{\beta}, \mathcal{M}_{\phi}, \mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$, under the assumptions of Proposition 2.14 the solution relaxes to a fixed Maxwellian $f \rightarrow \mu_{\sigma, u_{\infty}}$.

For a class of conservative models satisfying

$$
\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho}(x, y) \rho(x) \mathrm{d} x=\mathrm{s}_{\rho}(y)
$$

the momentum is conserved

$$
\bar{u}_{t}=\int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho}(x, y) u(y) \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y \rho(x) \mathrm{d} x-\int_{\Omega} \mathrm{s}_{\rho}(y) u(y) \rho(y) \mathrm{d} y=0
$$

So, in this case, $u_{\infty}=\bar{u}_{0}$. All symmetric models, $\phi_{\rho}(x, y)=\phi_{\rho}(y, x)$, are obviously conservative, including $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}, \mathcal{M}_{\phi}, \mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$. There are, however, examples of conservative non-symmetric models, see [Shv24a].

Let us now analyze and collect properties of a model necessary to achieve global relaxation starting from any data with higher finite momentum $f_{0} \in L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1} \cap L_{q}^{2}$. First, we need $\mathcal{M}$ to be of regular Schur's class in order to guarantee global existence of a weak solution by Theorem 2.10. This is not a restrictive class as all our core models are Schur by Lemma 2.6. Second, any such solution need to regularize to become classical, so $\mathcal{M}$ must satisfy the uniform $L^{2}$-to- $L^{\infty}$ regularization property (44). Third, we need to guarantee gain of thickness (i) uniformly in time. Proposition 2.11 provides a gain contingent upon uniform bounds on $\bar{H}$ and $\bar{W}$. In view of (44), $\bar{W}$ is controlled by the energy $\mathcal{E}$, which in turn is controlled by $\bar{H}$, which is controlled

by $\mathcal{H}$ thanks to (41). So, everything reduces to controlling the entropy. We can rewrite the entropy law in a different way:

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \mathcal{H}=-\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} s_{\rho} \frac{\left|\nabla_{v} f+(v-u) f\right|^{2}}{f} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x-\|u\|_{L^{2}\left(\kappa_{\rho}\right)}^{2}+\left(u,[u]_{\rho}\right)_{\kappa_{\rho}} \leqslant-\|u\|_{L^{2}\left(\kappa_{\rho}\right)}^{2}+\left(u,[u]_{\rho}\right)_{\kappa_{\rho}}
$$

If the averaging operator $[u]_{\rho}: L_{\kappa_{\rho}}^{2} \rightarrow L_{\kappa_{\rho}}^{2}$ is contractive, then $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t} \mathcal{H} \leqslant 0$, and hence $\mathcal{H} \leqslant \mathcal{H}_{0}$. It was shown in [Shv24a] that all conservative models are contractive. So, let us assume that $\mathcal{M}$ is conservative (which also implies the conclusion with $u_{\infty}=\bar{u}=\bar{u}_{0}$ ).

Forth, for many models the spectral gap condition (ii) is controlled by the thickness: for some $\varepsilon: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$,

$$
\varepsilon_{0} \geqslant \varepsilon(\theta(\rho, \Omega))
$$

A large class of models for which such estimates were obtained are symmetric positive-semi-definite models (or more generally ball-positive models, see [Shv24a]), $\left(u,[u]_{\rho}\right)_{\kappa_{\rho}} \geqslant 0$. These include $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}$ if the kernel is Bochner-positive, $\phi=\psi * \psi$,

$$
\left(u,[u]_{\rho}\right)_{\kappa_{\rho}}=\int_{\Omega}\left((u \rho) * \psi\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} x \geqslant 0
$$

the $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$-model,

$$
\left(u,[u]_{\rho}\right)_{\kappa_{\rho}}=\int_{\Omega} \frac{((u \rho) * \phi)^{2}}{\rho * \phi} \mathrm{~d} x \geqslant 0
$$

and $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$-model,

$$
\left(u,[u]_{\rho}\right)_{\kappa_{\rho}}=\sum_{l=1}^{L} g_{l}(x) \frac{\left(\int_{\Omega} u g_{l} \rho \mathrm{~d} y\right)^{2}}{\int_{\Omega} g_{l} \rho \mathrm{~d} y} \geqslant 0
$$

In particular, the statement applies to the following models

- the Cucker-Smale model $\mathcal{M}_{\text {CS }}$ with a Bochner-positive kernel $\phi=\psi * \psi$;
- the $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$-model with inf $\phi>0$;
- the segregation model $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$ with supp $g_{l}=\Omega$ for all $l=1, \ldots, L$.

Remark 2.17. The uniform $L^{2}$-to- $L^{\infty}$ mapping property (44) is the only property lacking by the $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$ and $\mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$ models with general kernels. One can however state a conditional result for solutions with uniformly bounded macroscopic velocities

$$
\sup _{t}\|u(t)\|_{\infty}<\infty
$$

Indeed, since $\left\|\left[\cdot\right]_{\rho}\right\|_{L^{\infty} \rightarrow L^{\infty}}=1$, the uniform control over $\bar{W}$ is guaranteed for such solutions. For the $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}$-model this result was proved in [Shv22].

What about non-symmetric models, such as $\mathcal{M}_{\text {MT }}$ ? Such models, despite the lack assumptions listed in Theorem 2.16, do possess them for almost uniformly distributed densities $\rho$, which applies to distributions $f$ located near the Maxwellian. Indeed, for all the core models $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}, \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}, \mathcal{M}_{\beta}$, with Bochner-positive $\phi$, and for $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}, \mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$, the spectral gap $\varepsilon_{0}$ and thickness $\theta$ will remain uniformly positive for any density sufficiently close to uniform (see [Shv24a, Propositions 4.16, 4.18])

$$
\|\rho-1 /|\Omega|\|_{1} \leqslant \delta_{0}
$$

At the same time, a modified Fisher information

$$
\tilde{\mathcal{I}}=c_{1} \mathcal{I}_{v v}+c_{2} \varepsilon \mathcal{I}_{x v}+c_{3} \mathcal{I}_{x x}+c_{4} \mathcal{H}, \quad \varepsilon \ll 1
$$

is a Lyapunov functional (as follows from the proof of Proposition 2.14),

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \tilde{\mathcal{I}} \leqslant-c \sigma \tilde{\mathcal{I}}
$$

where $c$ depends on $\theta$ and $\varepsilon_{0}$. So, if initially $\mathcal{I}\left(f_{0}\right) \leqslant c \sigma \delta_{0}$, then by the Csiszár-Kullback inequality, (53) holds, which in turn keeps $\mathcal{I}(f)$ small, and $f$ never leaves the neighborhood of Maxwellian, see [Shv24a, Proposition 8.5] for a formal stability argument. Theorem 2.18. For all the core models $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{CS}}, \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{MT}}, \mathcal{M}_{\beta}$, with Bochner-positive $\phi$, and for $\mathcal{M}_{\phi}, \mathcal{M}_{\text {seg }}$, there exists $\delta>0$ small enough but dependent on only the parameters of the model in question, such that for any data $f_{0} \in L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1} \cap L_{q}^{2}, q \gg 2$, with

$$

$$
\left\|f(t)-\mu_{\sigma, u_{\infty}}\right\|_{L^{1}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \leqslant c_{1} \delta^{1 / 2} e^{-c_{2} \sigma t}

# 3. Global existence of weak solutions 

In this section we prove all the statements of Theorem 2.10, except the uniqueness part which will be postponed till next section.
3.1. Approximation. Let us consider a modification of (1) where all the macroscopic densities are uniformly supported from below by a small parameter $\varepsilon>0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{t} f^{\varepsilon}+v \cdot \nabla_{x} f^{\varepsilon} & =\mathrm{s}^{\varepsilon} \nabla_{v} \cdot\left(\nabla_{v} f^{\varepsilon}+v f^{\varepsilon}\right)+\mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon} \cdot \nabla_{v} f^{\varepsilon} \\
\mathrm{s}^{\varepsilon}=\mathrm{s}_{\rho^{(\varepsilon)}} \quad \mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon}(x) & =\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho^{(\varepsilon)}}(x, y) u^{\varepsilon}(y) \rho^{\varepsilon}(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
\rho^{(\varepsilon)} & =\frac{\rho^{\varepsilon}+\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon} \in \mathcal{P}(\Omega)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $f_{0}^{\varepsilon}$ is a smooth truncation of the mollified initial condition $f_{0} \in L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}$, for example

$$
f_{0}^{\varepsilon}(x, v)=\chi(x, \varepsilon v) f_{0} * \chi_{\varepsilon}(x, v)
$$

where $\chi_{\varepsilon}$ is any approximating identity scaling of $\chi$ periodic in $x$. Note that

$$
\left\|f_{0}^{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}} \leqslant\left\|f_{0}\right\|_{L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}}
$$

and $f_{0}^{\varepsilon} \in H_{Q}^{M}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ for any $M, Q \in \mathbb{N}$.
Let us be mindful of the fact that $\rho^{(\varepsilon)}$ is not the macroscropic density of $f^{\varepsilon}$, and there is a disconnect between $\rho^{(\varepsilon)}$ and the native $\rho^{\varepsilon}$ in the definition of $\mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon}$. It is done intentionally to give the kernel a degree of regularity, be it $\varepsilon$-dependent, yet preserving the integrity of the pairing $u^{\varepsilon} \rho^{\varepsilon}$ in the integral operator. Since $\mathrm{s}^{\varepsilon}$ and $\phi_{\rho^{(\varepsilon)}}$ are uniformly in time in $C^{\infty}$ the proof of the local well-posedness theorem Theorem 2.3 applies in the obvious manner. Since the thickness is bounded from below by $\varepsilon$, the continuation criterion applies to yield global solution. Thus, the approximated system (55) gives rise to a global solution $f^{\varepsilon}$ in $H_{Q}^{M}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ for any $M, Q$.

Let us note that although the Sobolev norm is expected to deteriorate with $\varepsilon$, the energy

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\varepsilon}=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|v|^{2} f^{\varepsilon} \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} x
$$

remains exponentially bounded in time independently of $\varepsilon$. Indeed, we have the following equation

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \mathcal{E}^{\varepsilon}=-\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \mathrm{~s}^{\varepsilon}\left(v \cdot \nabla_{v} f^{\varepsilon}+|v|^{2} f^{\varepsilon}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} x+\left(\mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon}, u^{\varepsilon}\right)_{\rho^{\varepsilon}}
$$

After integration by parts in the first term we can see it is bounded by an absolute constant $n \bar{S}$. As to the macroscopic term $\left(\mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon}, u^{\varepsilon}\right)_{\rho^{\varepsilon}}$ we observe that the particular nature of the mollification $\mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon}$ allows to preserve its $L^{2}$-boundedness relative to the native density $\rho^{\varepsilon}$. We have

$$
\left\|\mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\rho^{\varepsilon}\right)}^{2}=\int_{\Omega}\left|\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho^{(\varepsilon)}}(x, y) u^{\varepsilon}(y) \rho^{\varepsilon}(y) \mathrm{d} y\right|^{2} \rho^{\varepsilon}(x) \mathrm{d} x
$$

Using that

$$
\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho^{(\varepsilon)}}(x, y) \rho^{\varepsilon}(y) \mathrm{d} y \leqslant(1+\varepsilon) \int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho^{(\varepsilon)}}(x, y) \rho^{(\varepsilon)}(y) \mathrm{d} y=(1+\varepsilon) \mathrm{s}^{\varepsilon}(x) \leqslant 2 \bar{S}
$$

Hence, by the Hölder inequality,

$$
\left\|\mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\rho^{\varepsilon}\right)}^{2} \leqslant 2 \bar{S} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho^{(\varepsilon)}}(x, y)\left|u^{\varepsilon}(y)\right|^{2} \rho^{\varepsilon}(y) \mathrm{d} y \rho^{\varepsilon}(x) \mathrm{d} x \leqslant 2 \overline{S r S}\left\|u^{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\rho^{\varepsilon}\right)}^{2}
$$

Thus,

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \mathcal{E}^{\varepsilon} \leqslant C_{1}+C_{2} \mathcal{E}^{\varepsilon}
$$

where $C_{1}, C_{2}$ are independent of $\varepsilon$, and consequently,

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\varepsilon}(t) \leqslant C e^{C t}
$$

for all $t>0$ and $C$ being independent of $\varepsilon$. In particular it follows that (55) is globally well-posed.
We can now use it as an approximation scheme to establish existence of global weak solutions to the original FPA (1). Let us record, as a consequence of (57) and (59) we have

$$
\left\|\mathrm{w}^{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\rho^{\varepsilon}\right)} \leqslant C_{T}
$$

Since $f^{\varepsilon} \in L^{\infty}\left([0, T] ; H_{Q}^{M}\right)$ its maximum is achieved on a ball $\Omega \times B_{R}(0)$ for all $t \in[0, T]$. So, by Rademacher's lemma, we can evaluate (55) at a point of maximum at any time and obtain

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t}\left\|f^{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\infty} \leqslant n \bar{S}\left\|f^{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\infty}
$$

Hence, one obtains a uniform bound on the density on $[0, T]$ independent of $\varepsilon$.
We have determined that

$$
f^{\varepsilon} \in L^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}\right)
$$

uniformly in $\varepsilon$. Moreover, from the equation (55) we also conclude $\partial_{t} f^{\varepsilon} \in L^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; H^{-2}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)\right.$ ), and from (61), $f^{\varepsilon} \in L^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; L^{2}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)\right)$. Since $L^{2} \hookrightarrow H^{-1}$ compactly, and $H^{-1} \subset H^{-2}$, by the Aubin-Lions Lemma, $\left\{f^{\varepsilon}\right\}_{\varepsilon} \subset C\left([0, T) ; H^{-1}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)\right)$ compactly. All the above implies that there exists a subsequence $f^{\varepsilon_{n}} \rightharpoonup f$ weakly in $L^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}\right)$ and strongly in $C\left([0, T) ; H^{-1}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)\right)$. Thus, the limiting function belongs to

$$
f \in L^{\infty}\left([0, T) ; L^{\infty} \cap L_{2}^{1}\right) \cap C\left([0, T) ; \mathcal{D}^{\prime}\left(\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)\right)
$$

as required in Definition 2.8 .
3.2. Averaging Lemma. In order to show that the limiting function is indeed a weak solution of (1) we need extra compactness provided by the the classical averaging lemma. To apply it let us make a few preparations. We can rewrite (55) as

$$
\partial_{t} f^{\varepsilon}+v \cdot \nabla_{x} f^{\varepsilon}=\Delta_{v}\left(g_{1}^{\varepsilon}\right)+\nabla_{v} \cdot g_{2}^{\varepsilon}

where

From (61) it is clear that $g_{1}^{\varepsilon} \in L_{t, x, v}^{2}$ uniformly on any time interval $[0, T]$. As to $g_{2}^{\varepsilon}$ :

$$

Since $f^{\varepsilon}$ solves the Cauchy problem, let us fix a time-cutoff function $h \in C_{0}^{\infty}(0, T)$, and rewrite (63) as follows

where $g_{3}^{\varepsilon}=f^{\varepsilon} \partial_{t} h$. Now, $h f^{\varepsilon}$ solves the equation on the entire time line $t \in \mathbb{R}$.

Then by the classical averaging lemma, see for example [Gla96, Theorem 7.2.1], we conclude that

$$

Let us recall that for a sequence $\varepsilon_{n} \rightarrow 0$ we already have $f^{\varepsilon_{n}} \rightarrow f$ weakly. By compactness of embedding $H_{0}^{1 / 6}([0, T] \times \Omega) \hookrightarrow L^{2}$ and uniqueness of the limit all the macroscopic quantities at hand converge in $L^{2}$-metric. Specifically, let us denote for short

$$
f^{n}=f^{\varepsilon_{n}}, \quad \rho^{n}=\rho^{\varepsilon_{n}}, \quad \rho_{\psi}^{n}=\rho_{\psi}^{\varepsilon_{n}}, \quad \rho^{(n)}=\rho^{\left(\varepsilon_{n}\right)}, \quad \text { etc, }

We have

for any $h \in C_{0}^{\infty}(0, t)$. The convergence (69) also extends to $[0, T)$ by observing that

# 4. Propagation of moments and uniqueness 

In this section we address propagation of moments from initial condition. We start by providing justification for the last claim in Theorem 2.10.

We know that the approximate sequence $f^{n}$ is regular and decays with any polynomial rate. So, we can test the equation (55) with $\langle v\rangle^{q}$ and justify all the computations classically. Denoting $\mathrm{m}_{q}^{n}=\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\langle v\rangle^{q} f^{n} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \mathrm{~m}_{q}^{n} & =\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \mathrm{~s}^{n} f^{n} \Delta_{v}\langle v\rangle^{q} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x+\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \mathrm{~s}^{n} f^{n} v \cdot \nabla_{v}\langle v\rangle^{q} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x+\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \mathrm{w}^{n} \cdot \nabla_{v}\langle v\rangle^{q} f^{n} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \\

\end{aligned}
$$

Using the Schur class conditions,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega}\left|\mathrm{w}^{n}\right|^{q} \rho^{n} \mathrm{~d} x & =\int_{\Omega}\left|\int_{\Omega} \phi_{\rho^{(n)}}(x, y) u^{n}(y) \rho^{n}(y) \mathrm{d} y\right|^{q} \rho^{n}(x) \mathrm{d} x \\

Thus, we obtain

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \mathrm{~m}_{q}^{n} \leqslant C \mathrm{~m}_{q}^{n}
$$

with $C$ independent of $n$. We thus conclude that $f^{n} \in L^{\infty} L_{q}^{1}$ uniformly, and in the limit obtain a solution in the same class.

We will make use of tapered moments as a way to approach a priori unbounded true moments. We consider

$$
\omega_{q, R}(v)=\langle v\rangle^{q}\langle v / R\rangle^{-Q}, \quad R>1, Q>q+n+1
$$

The important feature of this particular tapered moment is that it controls its higher weighted gradients, it's hierarchial-in- $q$, and it has doubling property, all independent of $R$ :

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(1+|v|^{k}\right)\left|\nabla_{v}^{k} \omega_{q, R}(v)\right| \leqslant C_{k} \omega_{q, R}(v), \quad k \in \mathbb{N} \\
\left|\nabla_{v}^{k} \omega_{q, R}(v)\right| \leqslant C_{k} \omega_{q-k, R}(v), \quad k \in \mathbb{N} \\

\end{gathered}
$$

In order to address the uniqueness we first need to show that the initial momentum $L_{q}^{2}$ is propagated in time for a given solution. This result is radically different from the one we obtained above in that we cannot rely on an a priori decay of the solution $f$ in $v$. $$

for all $t \in(0, T)$, and for some $\kappa, C>0$ depending on all the constants above.
Proof. We argue as in [Vil09, Lemma A.20]: in order to prove (130) it is sufficient to show that for any $E>0$ the length of the time interval $I \subset(0, T)$ on which $E / 2<\mathrm{h}<E$ is estimated by $|I| \lesssim 1 / E^{\kappa}, \kappa>0$. This will be done by showing the bound

$$
|I| E \lesssim \sum_{i=1}^{M}|I|^{\delta_{i}^{\prime}} E^{\delta_{i}^{\prime \prime}}
$$

for some $0 \leqslant \delta_{i}^{\prime}, \delta_{i}^{\prime \prime}<1$. Then picking the index $i$ for which the summand is maximal we achieve

$$
|I| \lesssim \frac{1}{E^{\left(1-\delta_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right) /\left(1-\delta_{i}^{\prime}\right)}}
$$

We assume without loss of generality that $E$ is larger than some fixed constant, namely, $E>1$ and $E>4 \bar{n}$, for otherwise the bound $|I| \lesssim 1 / E^{\kappa}$ is trivial. Also, by rescaling all quantities by $e^{-c_{2} t} \mathrm{~h}$ we can assume that

$$
\dot{\mathrm{h}} \leqslant-c_{1} \mathrm{~d}
$$

Denoting $I=\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)$ and integrating of the above over $I$ we have

$$
\int_{I} \mathrm{~d}(t) \mathrm{d} t \lesssim \mathrm{~h}\left(t_{1}\right) \leqslant E
$$

Noting that $\mathrm{x} \leqslant E$, we have

$$
\int_{I} \mathrm{v} \mathrm{~d} t \lesssim \sum_{i=1}^{N} \int_{I} \mathrm{x}^{\theta_{i}^{\prime}} \mathrm{d}^{\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}} \mathrm{d} t \leqslant \sum_{i=1}^{N}|I|^{1-\theta_{i}^{\prime}-\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}}\left(\int_{I} \mathrm{x} \mathrm{~d} t\right)^{\theta_{i}^{\prime}}\left(\int_{I} \mathrm{~d} \mathrm{~d} t\right)^{\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}} \leqslant \sum_{i=1}^{N}|I|^{1-\theta_{i}^{\prime}-\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}} E^{\theta_{i}^{\prime}+\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}|I|^{1-\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}} E^{\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}}
$$

where $0<\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}=\theta_{i}^{\prime}+\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}<1$.
Next, from the m-equation, and (129),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{I} \mathrm{x} \mathrm{~d} t & \lesssim\left|\mathrm{~m}\left(t_{1}\right)\right|+\left|\mathrm{m}\left(t_{2}\right)\right|+\int_{I} \mathrm{v} \mathrm{~d} t+\int_{I} \mathrm{v}^{1 / 2} \mathrm{~d}^{1 / 2} \mathrm{~d} t+\int_{I} 1 \mathrm{~d} t \\
& \lesssim \sum_{i}\left(E^{\theta_{i}}+|I|^{1-\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}} E^{\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}}\right)+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N}|I|^{1-\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}} E^{\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}}\right)^{1 / 2} E^{1 / 2}+1
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that 1 can be thought of as $|I|^{\bar{n}} E^{0}$, so it fits within the allowed range of powers. Reindexing, we obtain

$$
\int_{I} \mathrm{x} \mathrm{~d} t \lesssim \sum_{i}|I|^{\delta_{i}^{\prime}} E^{\delta_{i}^{\prime \prime}}
$$

Since $E>4 \bar{n}$, we have $\mathrm{x}+\mathrm{v} \geqslant E / 4$, and hence, from the above,

$$
|I| E \lesssim \int_{I}(\mathrm{x}+\mathrm{v}) \mathrm{d} t \lesssim \sum_{i}|I|^{\mathrm{d}_{i}^{i}} E^{\mathrm{d}_{i}^{i \prime}}
$$

which finishes the proof.
This finishes the proof of Theorem 5.1.

# 6. APPENDIX: INTERPOLATION IN WEIGHTED SOBOLEV SPACES 

For any any $p \in \mathbb{N}$ we denote for short $\partial_{p}^{p} f=\left(\partial_{x_{1}}^{p} f, \ldots, \partial_{x_{n}}^{p} f\right)$, and $\left|\partial_{x}^{p} f\right|^{2}=\sum_{i}\left|\partial_{x_{i}}^{p} f\right|^{2}$. Similar notation will be used in $v$-variable. It is clear that $\left|\partial_{p}^{p} f\right|^{2}$ represents a linear combination of $p$ th order derivatives.

Let us first note the following simple interpolation inequality: for $k, l \geqslant 0$ and $K, L>0$ such that $\frac{k}{K}+\frac{l}{L}<1$ and any $|\mathbf{k}|=k,|\mathbf{l}|=l$, we have

$$
\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{k} \partial_{v}^{l} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \leqslant\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{K} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\frac{k}{L}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{v}^{L} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\frac{1}{L}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|f|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{1-\frac{k}{K}-\frac{1}{L}}
$$

Indeed, denoting by $\mathrm{d} \xi$ the counting measure over $\mathbb{Z}^{n}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x= & \int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \Pi_{i=1}^{n}\left|\xi_{i}\right|^{2 k_{i}}\left|\eta_{i}\right|^{2 l_{i}}|\hat{f}|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi \leqslant \int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|\xi|^{2 k}|\eta|^{2 l}|\hat{f}|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi \\
\leqslant & \int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|\xi|^{2 k}|\hat{f}|^{2 k / K}|\eta|^{2 l}|\hat{f}|^{2 l / L}|\hat{f}|^{2(1-k / K-l / K)} \mathrm{d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi \\
\leqslant & \left(\int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|\xi|^{2 K}|\hat{f}|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi\right)^{\frac{k}{K}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|\eta|^{2 L}|\hat{f}|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi\right)^{\frac{1}{L}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|f|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi\right)^{1-\frac{k}{K}-\frac{1}{L}} \\
& \leq\left(\sum_{i} \int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\xi_{i}\right|^{2 K}|\hat{f}|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi\right)^{\frac{1}{K}}\left(\sum_{i} \int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\eta_{i}\right|^{2 L}|\hat{f}|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi\right)^{\frac{1}{L}} \\
& \quad \times\left(\int_{\mathbb{Z}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|f|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \xi\right)^{1-\frac{k}{K}-\frac{1}{L}} \\
= & \left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{K} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\frac{k}{L}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{v}^{L} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\frac{1}{L}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|f|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{1-\frac{k}{K}-\frac{1}{L}}
\end{aligned}
$$

When a weight is involved that depends only on $v, \omega=\omega(v)$, then the above interpolation extends trivially in the case when $\mathbf{k}=0$ by application of (131) in $x$-variable only, and the Hölder inequality in $v$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \leqslant \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left(\int_{\Omega}\left|\partial_{x}^{K} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\frac{k}{K}}\left(\int_{\Omega}|f|^{2} \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{1-\frac{k}{K}} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \\
\leqslant\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{K} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\frac{k}{K}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|f|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{1-\frac{k}{K}}
\end{aligned}
$$

It is clear that the above inequalities extend to any fractional $k, K$ as well if we replace the derivatives with Fourier multipliers $D_{x}^{k} f$ with symbol $|\xi|^{k}$. In fact the computations above already use that symbol even for integer order derivatives. It is important to keep in mind though that if $k$ is integer, then since $\omega$ is not involved in Fourier transform, we have

$$
\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|D_{x}^{k} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \sim \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{k} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x
$$

In other words we can go back to the classical derivatives.
Lemma 6.1. Suppose $\omega$ is a doubling weight,

$$
\begin{aligned}
c \leqslant \frac{\omega\left(v^{\prime}\right)}{\omega\left(v^{\prime \prime}\right)} & \leqslant C, \quad \frac{1}{2} \leqslant \frac{\left|v^{\prime}\right|}{\left|v^{\prime \prime}\right|} \leqslant 2 \\
\omega(v) & \sim 1, \quad|v| \leqslant 1
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $k, l \geqslant 0$ and $K, L>0$ such that $\frac{k}{K}+\frac{l}{L}<1$, and let $|\mathbf{k}|=k,|\mathbf{l}|=l$. Then there exists constants $N \in \mathbb{N}$, $0 \leqslant \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}, \theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime} \leqslant 1$ with $\theta_{i}^{\prime}+\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}+\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}=1$ and $\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime \prime}>0$, that depend only on $k, K, l, L$, such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} & \left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}} f\right|^{2} \omega d v d x \\
& \leqslant \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{v}^{K} f\right|^{2} \omega d v d x\right)^{\theta_{i}^{\prime}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \sum_{l^{\prime} \leqslant L}\left|\partial_{v}^{l^{\prime}} f\right|^{2} \omega d v d x\right)^{\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|f|^{2} \omega d v d x\right)^{\theta_{i}^{\prime \prime}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $K$ can be fractional with $\partial_{x}^{K}$ being interpreted as above.
Proof. We argue by induction on $\mu$. For the base case when $\mu=0$, the inequality has been proved above.
Let us now assume that $\mu \geqslant 1$ and the inequality holds for the indices up to $\mu-1$. We will use the Littlewood-Paley decomposition of the kinetic $v$-space. Fix $\phi \in C^{\infty}, \phi(r)=1$ for $r<1 / 2$, and $\phi(r)=0$ for $r>1$. Define, $\psi^{2}(r)=\phi(r / 2)-\phi(r)$, and $\psi_{p}^{2}=\psi^{2}\left(r / 2^{p}\right), \psi_{-1}^{2}=\phi$. Then $\sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \psi_{p}^{2}=1$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x & =\sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}}\left(\psi_{p} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}} f\right)\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \\
& \leqslant \sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}}\left(\psi_{p} f\right)\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x+\sum_{\mathbf{l}^{\prime}<1} \sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}-\mathbf{l}^{\prime}} \psi_{p}\right|^{2}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}^{\prime}} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\left|\partial_{v}^{\mu-m} \psi_{p}\right|^{2}$ is a geometrically decreasing sequence of functions supported on the dyadic shell $\left\{2^{p-1} \leqslant|v| \leqslant 2^{p+1}\right\}$. The shells overlap at most by two, so the last sum adds up to

$$
\lesssim \sum_{\mathbf{l}^{\prime}<1} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}^{\prime}} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x
$$

By the induction hypothesis all these terms are bounded as desired. So, let us focus on the main term. Using (131), and the doubling property of the weight,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}}\left(\psi_{p} f\right)\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \sim \sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \omega\left(2^{p}\right) \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{\mathbf{k}} \partial_{v}^{\mathbf{l}}\left(\psi_{p} f\right)\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \\
& \lesssim \sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \omega\left(2^{p}\right)\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \psi_{p}^{2}\left|\partial_{x}^{K} f\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\frac{k}{K}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{v}^{L}\left(\psi_{p} f\right)\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\frac{l}{L}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \psi_{p}^{2}|f|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{1-\frac{k}{K}-\frac{l}{L}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Distributing the weights $\omega\left(2^{p}\right)$ inside the integrals, we use again the doubling property noting that each integral is over the $p$-th dyadic shell,

$$
\lesssim \sum_{p=-1}^{\infty}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \psi_{p}^{2}\left|\partial_{x}^{K} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{v}^{L}\left(\psi_{p} f\right)\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime \prime}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \psi_{p}^{2}|f|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime \prime \prime}}
$$

and by the Hölder inequality,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lesssim\left(\sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \psi_{p}^{2}\left|\partial_{x}^{K} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime}}\left(\sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{v}^{L}\left(\psi_{p} f\right)\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime \prime}}\left(\sum_{p=-1}^{\infty} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \psi_{p}^{2}|f|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime \prime \prime}} \\
& \lesssim\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{x}^{K} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime}}\left(\sum_{l^{\prime} \leqslant L} \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}\left|\partial_{v}^{\prime} f\right|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime \prime \prime}}\left(\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}}|f|^{2} \omega \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x\right)^{\theta^{\prime \prime \prime}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which has the required form.

Lemma 6.2. Suppose $\omega$ is a doubling weight and $f_{\varepsilon}$ denotes convolution with the standard compactly supported mollifier $\chi_{\varepsilon}$. Then

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}(\omega)} \leqslant C\|f\|_{L^{2}(\omega)} \\
\left\|f-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}(\omega)} \rightarrow 0, \text { as } \varepsilon \rightarrow 0
\end{gathered}
$$

Proof. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}(\omega)}^{2} & \leqslant \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \chi_{\varepsilon}(y, w) \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \omega(v)|f(x-y, v-w)|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} w \mathrm{~d} y \\
& =\int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \chi_{\varepsilon}(y, w) \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \omega(v)|f(x, v-w)|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} w \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

If $|v| \leqslant 1$, then $|v-w| \leqslant 2$ for small $\varepsilon$, and thus, $\omega(v) \sim \omega(v-w) \sim 1$. Otherwise, if $|v|>1$, then $\omega(v) / \omega(v-w) \sim 1$ by the doubling property. Hence,

$$
\left\|f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}(\omega)}^{2} \lesssim \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \chi_{\varepsilon}(y, w) \int_{\Omega \times \mathbb{R}^{n}} \omega(v-w)|f(x, v-w)|^{2} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} w \mathrm{~d} y=\|f\|_{L^{2}(\omega)}^{2}
$$

The convergence (136) follows from the standard Lebesgue theory.

In this paper we prove global existence of weak solutions, their
regularization, and global relaxation to Maxwellian for a broad class of
Fokker-Planck-Alignment models which appear in collective dynamics. The main
feature of these results, as opposed to previously known ones, is the lack of
regularity or no-vacuum requirements on the initial data. With a particular
application to the classical kinetic Cucker-Smale model, we demonstrate that
any bounded data with finite energy, $(1+ |v|^2) f_0 \in L^1$, $f_0 \in
L^\infty$, and finite higher moment $|v|^q f\in L^2$, $q \gg 2$, gives rise to
a global instantly smooth solution, satisfying entropy equality and relaxing
exponentially fast.
  The results are achieved through the use of a new thickness-based
renormalization, which circumvents the problem of degenerate diffusion in
non-perturbative regime.
